title: Quiz Demo
text:
NoteLearning Objectives




Practice writing R expressions and functions
Work with vectors, data frames, and basic statistics
Get immediate feedback by running your code in the browser

title: Quiz Demo
text:
Knowledge Check
Write your answers in the code editors below and click Run Code to check your work. Expand the answer sections if you get stuck.


Question 1: Sequences
What function in R creates a sequence of integers from 1 to 10?

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.






TipShow Answer





1:10
# or
seq(1, 10)






Question 2: Summary Statistics
Using base R, calculate the mean of the vector c(4, 8, 15, 16, 23, 42).

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.






TipShow Answer





mean(c(4, 8, 15, 16, 23, 42))
# Answer: 18






Question 3: Data Frames
Create a data frame with two columns: name (with values “Alice”, “Bob”, “Carol”) and score (with values 90, 85, 92). Then filter to only rows where score > 88.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.






TipShow Answer





df <- data.frame(
  name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol"),
  score = c(90, 85, 92)
)
df[df$score > 88, ]

Test Pages

Palmer Penguins Explorer – Static R output with ggplot2 plots, gt summary tables, and Bootstrap tabsets.

title: Shinylive Demo
text:
NoteLearning Objectives




See how Shiny apps can run without a server using Shinylive
Explore how reactive inputs (sliders) update outputs (plots) in real time
Observe the effect of sample size, mean, and standard deviation on a distribution

title: Shinylive Demo
text:
Client-Side Shiny App
This Shiny app runs entirely in the browser via Shinylive – no server required. Use the sliders to explore how parameters affect the normal distribution.

#| '!! shinylive warning !!': |
#|   shinylive does not work in self-contained HTML documents.
#|   Please set `embed-resources: false` in your metadata.
#| standalone: true
#| viewerHeight: 500

library(shiny)

ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Normal Distribution Explorer"),
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      sliderInput("n", "Number of observations:", min = 50, max = 1000, value = 200),
      sliderInput("mean", "Mean:", min = -5, max = 5, value = 0, step = 0.5),
      sliderInput("sd", "Standard deviation:", min = 0.5, max = 5, value = 1, step = 0.5)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("histogram")
    )
  )
)

server <- function(input, output) {
  output$histogram <- renderPlot({
    data <- rnorm(input$n, mean = input$mean, sd = input$sd)
    hist(data, breaks = 30, col = "steelblue", border = "white",
         main = paste("n =", input$n, " mean =", input$mean, " sd =", input$sd),
         xlab = "Value")
  })
}

shinyApp(ui, server)






TipTry It Yourself




Set the standard deviation to 0.5 and the number of observations to 1000. How does the histogram shape compare to sd = 5?
Move the mean slider and watch how the entire distribution shifts along the x-axis.

title: Palmer Penguins Explorer
text:
NoteLearning Objectives




Visualize relationships between penguin body measurements
Compare species distributions across islands using plots and tables
Explore grouped summaries with interactive tabsets
Code
library(palmerpenguins)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(gt)

title: Palmer Penguins Explorer
text:
Overview
The Palmer Penguins dataset contains measurements for 344 penguins from three species observed on three islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica.

title: Palmer Penguins Explorer
text:
Scatter Plot


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species, shape = species)) +
  geom_point(size = 2.5, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple", "cyan4")) +
  labs(
    x = "Flipper Length (mm)",
    y = "Body Mass (g)",
    color = "Species",
    shape = "Species"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








Figure 1: Flipper length vs. body mass by species

title: Palmer Penguins Explorer
text:
Summary Table


Code
penguins |>
  filter(!is.na(body_mass_g)) |>
  group_by(species) |>
  summarise(
    Count = n(),
    `Mean Body Mass (g)` = round(mean(body_mass_g), 0),
    `Mean Flipper Length (mm)` = round(mean(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
    `Mean Bill Length (mm)` = round(mean(bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
    `Mean Bill Depth (mm)` = round(mean(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE), 1)
  ) |>
  gt() |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Penguin Species Summary",
    subtitle = "Averages across all islands"
  ) |>
  cols_label(species = "Species") |>
  tab_source_note("Source: palmerpenguins R package")

title: Palmer Penguins Explorer
text:
Details by Island

BiscoeDreamTorgersen




Code
penguins |>
  filter(island == "Biscoe") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7, show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkorange", "cyan4")) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Body Mass (g)") +
  theme_minimal()













Code
penguins |>
  filter(island == "Dream") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7, show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple")) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Body Mass (g)") +
  theme_minimal()













Code
penguins |>
  filter(island == "Torgersen") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7, show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkorange")) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Body Mass (g)") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Palmer Penguins Explorer
text:
About the Data






TipData Collection Details





The Palmer Penguins dataset was collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman and the Palmer Station, Antarctica LTER, a member of the Long Term Ecological Research Network. The data were collected from 2007–2009 and include the following variables:

species: Adelie, Chinstrap, or Gentoo
island: Biscoe, Dream, or Torgersen
bill_length_mm: Length of the bill (mm)
bill_depth_mm: Depth of the bill (mm)
flipper_length_mm: Flipper length (mm)
body_mass_g: Body mass (g)
sex: Male or Female
year: Study year (2007, 2008, or 2009)

This dataset is commonly used as an alternative to the iris dataset for data exploration and visualization examples.









TipMissing Values







Code
penguins |>
  summarise(across(everything(), ~ sum(is.na(.)))) |>
  gt() |>
  tab_header(title = "Missing Values per Column")
